steps.description: Call 102(Nepal's Context) immediately or have someone else do it. Ask for an AED if available.
Place the person on their back on a firm surface. Tilt their head back slightly and open their airway.
Place the heel of one hand on the center of their chest, between the nipples. Place your other hand on top, interlocking your fingers.
Position yourself directly over their chest. Keep your arms straight and push hard and fast at least 2 inches deep.
Push at a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute. Allow complete chest recoil between compressions.
After 30 compressions, give 2 rescue breaths. Tilt their head back, lift their chin, and breathe into their mouth.
Continue cycles of 30 compressions and 2 breaths until emergency help arrives or the person starts breathing.
Ask 'Are you choking?' If they can't speak, cough, or breathe, begin first aid immediately.
Stand behind the person and wrap your arms around their waist.
Make a fist with one hand and place it just above their navel, below the ribcage.
Grasp your fist with your other hand and give quick, upward thrusts into their abdomen.
Continue until the object is expelled or the person becomes unconscious.
If the person becomes unconscious, call 911 and begin CPR.
Remove the person from the heat source immediately and ensure their safety.
Cool the burn with cool (not cold) running water for 10-20 minutes.
Remove any jewelry or tight clothing from the burned area before swelling begins.
Do not use ice, butter, or other home remedies on the burn.
Cover the burn with a sterile, non-stick bandage or clean cloth.
Take over-the-counter pain relievers if needed and seek medical attention if the burn is larger than 3 inches.
Wash your hands thoroughly or use hand sanitizer before treating the wound.
Apply direct pressure to the wound with a clean cloth or sterile bandage.
Elevate the injured area above the heart if possible to reduce bleeding.
If blood soaks through the bandage, add more layers without removing the original.
Once bleeding stops, clean the wound gently with water and apply antibiotic ointment.
Cover with a sterile bandage and change daily. Seek medical attention if deep or won't stop bleeding.
Rest the injured area and avoid activities that cause pain.
Ice the area for 15-20 minutes every 2-3 hours for the first 48 hours.
Compress the area with an elastic bandage, but not too tightly to restrict blood flow.
Elevate the injured area above heart level when possible to reduce swelling.
Take over-the-counter pain relievers as directed on the package.
Seek medical attention if you can't bear weight, have severe pain, or suspect a fracture.
Stay calm and time the seizure. Call 911 if it lasts longer than 5 minutes.
Clear the area around the person of any hard or sharp objects.
Do not hold the person down or put anything in their mouth.
Turn the person onto one side to prevent choking if they vomit.
Place something soft under their head if possible.
Stay with the person until they are fully alert. Call 911 if this is their first seizure or if they are injured.
Call 102(Nepal's Context) immediately. Do not drive the person to the hospital yourself.
Help the person sit down and rest, preferably in a comfortable position.
Loosen any tight clothing around the neck, chest, and waist.
If the person takes heart medication (like nitroglycerin), help them take it as prescribed.
Give them aspirin to chew if they are not allergic and it's available.
Monitor their breathing and pulse. Be prepared to perform CPR if they become unconscious.
Call 102(Nepal's Context) immediately if the person has difficulty breathing, swelling of face/throat, or severe symptoms.
Help the person avoid the allergen if it's known and still present.
If the person has an epinephrine auto-injector (EpiPen), help them use it immediately.
Have the person lie down with legs elevated, unless they have trouble breathing.
Loosen tight clothing and cover with a blanket.
Monitor their breathing and be prepared to perform CPR if needed. Do not give anything by mouth.
Have the person sit upright and lean slightly forward to prevent blood from running down the throat.
Pinch the soft part of the nose firmly with thumb and index finger.
Hold for 10-15 minutes without checking if bleeding has stopped.
Apply ice to the bridge of the nose to help constrict blood vessels.
If bleeding continues after 15 minutes of direct pressure, seek medical attention.
Avoid blowing the nose for several hours after bleeding stops.
If the person feels faint, help them lie down with legs elevated above heart level.
Loosen any tight clothing, especially around the neck and waist.
Check for breathing and pulse. If absent, call 911 and begin CPR.
If breathing normally, keep them lying down for several minutes before helping them sit up slowly.
Offer water once they are fully alert and can sit up without dizziness.
Seek medical attention if fainting was preceded by chest pain, shortness of breath, or if it's their first episode.
Move the person to a cool, shaded area or air-conditioned space immediately.
Remove excess clothing and loosen tight clothing.
Apply cool, wet cloths to the skin or have them take a cool shower if able.
Give small sips of cool water if the person is conscious and able to swallow.
Fan the person to help with cooling through evaporation.
Call 911 if symptoms worsen, temperature rises above 104Â°F, or if vomiting occurs.
Call 102(Nepal's Context) immediately for severe hypothermia. Move the person to a warm, dry area.
Remove wet clothing gently and replace with dry, loose layers.
Cover the person with blankets, leaving only the face exposed.
Apply warm, dry compresses to neck, chest, and groin areas only.
Give warm, non-alcoholic, non-caffeinated drinks if the person is conscious.
Do not rub or massage the person, as this can cause dangerous heart rhythm changes.
Do not rub the eye or try to remove objects embedded in the eye.
For small particles, try to flush the eye with clean water or saline solution.
Pull the upper eyelid over the lower eyelid to help tears wash out particles.
If unsuccessful, cover both eyes with sterile gauze to prevent eye movement.
For chemical exposure, flush continuously with water for at least 15 minutes.
Seek immediate medical attention for embedded objects, chemicals, or persistent pain.
Call Poison Control immediately at 1-800-222-1222 or 911 for severe symptoms.
Try to identify what was ingested, how much, and when it occurred.
Do not induce vomiting unless specifically instructed by Poison Control.
If the person is unconscious, position them on their side to prevent choking.
Save the container or substance for identification by medical professionals.
Follow all instructions from Poison Control or emergency services exactly.
Do not move the person unless they are in immediate danger. Call 911.
Keep the injured area still and supported in the position found.
Apply ice wrapped in a cloth to reduce swelling, but not directly on skin.
If bone is visible through the skin, cover with sterile gauze but do not push it back in.
Create a splint using available materials to immobilize the area above and below the injury.
Monitor for signs of shock: pale skin, rapid pulse, dizziness, or nausea.
